title: Visualising multi-state models using mstate
text: purpose present vignette demonstrate visualisation capacities mstate, using base R graphics ggplot2 package (Wickham 2016). , use dataset used illustrate competing risks analyses Section 3 Tutorial Putter, Fiocco, Geskus (2007) . dataset available mstate object name aidssi. can begin loading mstate ggplot2 libraries, set general theme plots: can proceed load dataset, prepare competing risks analysis using msprep(). steps described detail main vignette.
code: # Load libraries library(mstate) #> Loading required package: survival library(ggplot2)  # Set general ggplot2 theme theme_set(theme_bw(base_size = 14)) # Load data data("aidssi") head(aidssi) #>   patnr   time status      cause ccr5 #> 1     1  9.106      1       AIDS   WW #> 2     2 11.039      0 event-free   WM #> 3     3  2.234      1       AIDS   WW #> 4     4  9.878      2         SI   WM #> 5     5  3.819      1       AIDS   WW #> 6     6  6.801      1       AIDS   WW  # Shorter name si <- aidssi  # Prepare transition matrix tmat <- trans.comprisk(2, names = c("event-free", "AIDS", "SI")) tmat #>             to #> from         event-free AIDS SI #>   event-free         NA    1  2 #>   AIDS               NA   NA NA #>   SI                 NA   NA NA  # Run msprep si$stat1 <- as.numeric(si$status == 1) si$stat2 <- as.numeric(si$status == 2)  silong <- msprep(   time = c(NA, "time", "time"),    status = c(NA, "stat1", "stat2"),    data = si,    keep = "ccr5",    trans = tmat )  # Run cox model silong <- expand.covs(silong, "ccr5")  c1 <- coxph(Surv(time, status) ~ ccr5WM.1 + ccr5WM.2 + strata(trans),             data = silong)

what: Visualising cumulative baseline hazards using plot.msfit()
title: Visualising multi-state models using mstate
text: Using msfit(), can obtain patient-specific transition hazards. look patient CCR5 genotype “WW” (wild type allele chromosomes). cumulative baseline hazards can plotted simply using:  specify argument use.ggplot = TRUE, plot method return ggplot object.  using argument type = "separate", base R plot return separate plot transition:  ggplot2 version return facetted plot, axis scales can either kept “fixed”, “free” using scale_type argument. essentially argument scales facet_wrap() function ggplot2, see ?ggplot2::facet_wrap.   remaining arguments standard plotting adjustments, work ggplot2 base R version plots. details, see ?mstate::plot.msfit. adjustments available function arguments (plot title) can simply added using standard ggplot2 syntax using +, graphics functions title(). following customised example:   Available using use.ggplot = TRUE confidence intervals around cumulative hazards, can obtained specifying conf.type type “plain” “log”, example single plot:  else, facetted plot:
code: # Data to predict WW <- data.frame(   ccr5WM.1 = c(0, 0),   ccr5WM.2 = c(0, 0),    trans = c(1, 2),    strata = c(1, 2) )  # Make msfit object msf.WW <- msfit(   object = c1,    newdata = WW,    trans = tmat ) plot(msf.WW) plot(msf.WW, use.ggplot = TRUE) par(mfrow = c(1, 2)) plot(msf.WW, type = "separate") # Fixed scales plot(msf.WW, type = "separate", use.ggplot = TRUE, scale_type = "fixed") # Free scales plot(msf.WW, type = "separate", use.ggplot = TRUE, scale_type = "free", xlim = c(0, 15)) par(mfrow = c(1, 1)) # A base R customised plot plot(   msf.WW,    type = "single",    cols = c("blue", "black"), # or numeric e.g. c(1, 2)   xlim = c(0, 15),   legend.pos = "top",   lty = c("dashed", "solid"),   use.ggplot = FALSE ) title("Cumulative baseline hazards") # A ggplot2 customised plot plot(   msf.WW,    type = "single",    cols = c("blue", "black"), # or numeric e.g. c(1, 2)   xlim = c(0, 15),   lty = c("dashed", "solid"),   legend.pos = "bottom",   use.ggplot = TRUE ) +      # Add title and center   ggtitle("Cumulative baseline hazards") +   theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5)) plot(   msf.WW,    type = "single",    use.ggplot = TRUE,   conf.type = "log",    conf.int = 0.95 ) plot(   msf.WW,    type = "separate",    use.ggplot = TRUE,   conf.type = "log",    conf.int = 0.95,   scale_type = "free_y" )

title: Visualising multi-state models using mstate
text: transition hazards obtained previous section can used obtain patient-specific transition probabilities using probtrans(). , like predict beginning follow-(predt = 0). plot method probtrans objects allows visualise transition probabilities various ways, using functionality base R graphics ggplot2.

title: Visualising multi-state models using mstate
text: default -called “filled” plot, transition probabilities represented coloured areas. argument allows user choose state predict (default 1, first state).  , use.ggplot = TRUE argument can used return ggplot object instead:  Note ggplot2 version plot places state labels legend rather labels plot . prefer latter, can specify label = annotate instead - change size labels cex.  generally, can also adjust stacking order using ord argument, takes numeric vector equal number states, desired stacking order (bottom top).  can also choose forgo colour, specify type = "stacked" instead:
code: plot(pt.WW, from = 1) # from = 1 implied plot(pt.WW, use.ggplot = TRUE) plot(pt.WW, use.ggplot = TRUE, label = "annotate", cex = 6) # Check state order again from transition matrix tmat #>             to #> from         event-free AIDS SI #>   event-free         NA    1  2 #>   AIDS               NA   NA NA #>   SI                 NA   NA NA  # Plot aids (state 2), then event-free (state 1), and SI on top (state 3) plot(pt.WW, use.ggplot = TRUE, ord = c(2, 1, 3)) plot(pt.WW, use.ggplot = TRUE, type = "stacked")

what: Single and separate plots, confidence intervals
title: Visualising multi-state models using mstate
text: Instead visualising probabilities using stacked areas, can go traditional route use single line per state. Confidence intervals can added. specifying type = "separate", base R plot return separate plot three states.  ggplot2 version return facetted plot, one state per facet. also accommodates confidence intervals, either type “log” (default) “plain”.  confidence intervals can omitted using conf.type = "none". wanted one plot? , can use type = single option:  , confidence intervals can omitted.  multi-state model large, may interested plotting probabilities subset states together. subset sum 1, stacked/filled plots appropriate. set function , can done extracting data plot.probtrans()-based ggplot object follows:  interest lies plotting probability single state, procedure can used, vis.multiple.pt() function presented used directly.
code: par(mfrow = c(1, 3)) plot(pt.WW, type = "separate") plot(   pt.WW,    use.ggplot = TRUE,    type = "separate",   conf.int = 0.95, # 95% level   conf.type = "log" ) plot(   pt.WW,    use.ggplot = TRUE,    type = "single",   conf.int = 0.95, # 95% level   conf.type = "log" ) plot(   pt.WW,    use.ggplot = TRUE,    type = "single",   conf.type = "none",   lty = c(1, 2, 3), # change the linetype   lwd = 1.5,  ) # Run plot and extract data using $data dat_plot <- plot(x = pt.WW, use.ggplot = TRUE, type = "single")$data    # Begin new plot - Exclude or select states to be plotted ggplot(data = dat_plot[state != "event-free", ], aes(   x = time,    y = prob,    ymin = CI_low,    ymax = CI_upp,   group = state,   linetype = state,   col = state )) +      # Add CI and lines; change fill = NA to remove CIs   geom_ribbon(col = NA, fill = "gray", alpha = 0.5) +   geom_line() +      # Remaining details   labs(x = "Time", y = "Cumulative Incidence") +   coord_cartesian(ylim = c(0, 1), xlim = c(0, 14), expand = 0)

title: Visualising multi-state models using mstate
text: Cuminc() function mstate produces (competing risks data) non-parametric Aalen-Johansen estimates cumulative incidence functions. obtained cmrpsk package function cuminc(). mstate, object class “Cuminc” can also plotted follows:  case grouping variable:
code: cum_incid <- Cuminc(   time = "time",   status = "status",   data = si )  plot(   x = cum_incid,   use.ggplot = TRUE,   conf.type = "log",   lty = 1:2,   conf.int = 0.95, ) cum_incid_grp <- Cuminc(   time = "time",   status = "status",   group = "ccr5",   data = si )  plot(   x = cum_incid_grp,   use.ggplot = TRUE,   conf.type = "none",   lty = 1:4,    facet = FALSE ) plot(   x = cum_incid_grp,   use.ggplot = TRUE,   conf.type = "none",   lty = 1:4,    facet = TRUE )

title: Visualising multi-state models using mstate
text: may also interested comparing predicted probabilities multiple reference patients. First, need create many msfit/probtrans objects reference patients interest: Afterwards, can supply probtrans objects list vis.multiple.pt() function. visualise probability state number time, given reference patient state number predt time supplied probtrans(). example visualises probability state AIDS, given event-free time 0. two lines/associated confidence intervals correspond reference patients - different CCR5 genotype (“WW” “WM”).  function just well used single probtrans object:  Note function available ggplot format.
code: # 1. Prepare patient data - both CCR5 genotypes WW <- data.frame(   ccr5WM.1 = c(0, 0),    ccr5WM.2 = c(0, 0),    trans = c(1, 2),    strata = c(1, 2) )  WM <- data.frame(   ccr5WM.1 = c(1, 0),    ccr5WM.2 = c(0, 1),   trans = c(1, 2),    strata = c(1, 2) )  # 2. Make msfit objects msf.WW <- msfit(c1, WW, trans = tmat) msf.WM <- msfit(c1, WM, trans = tmat)  # 3. Make probtrans objects pt.WW <- probtrans(msf.WW, predt = 0) pt.WM <- probtrans(msf.WM, predt = 0) vis.multiple.pt(   x = list(pt.WW, pt.WM),    from = 1,   to = 2,    conf.type = "log",   cols = c(1, 2),   labels = c("Pat WW", "Pat WM"),   legend.title = "Ref patients" ) vis.multiple.pt(   x = list(pt.WW),    from = 1,   to = 2,    conf.type = "log",   cols = c(1, 2),   labels = c("Pat WW", "Pat WM"),   legend.title = "Ref patients" )

title: Visualising multi-state models using mstate
text: Multiple probtrans objects can also compared means mirrored plot. idea compare probabilities () states two references patients particular horizon. addition reference patients, different subsets data equally compared.  Omitting horizon argument default plotting sides respective maximum follow-time, may asymmetric. thus recommend always use horizon argument. example time years, follow-extremely short, may want override breaks x-axis. can done using breaks_x_left breaks_x_right arguments.
code: vis.mirror.pt(   x = list(pt.WW, pt.WM),   titles = c("WW", "WM"),   horizon = 10 ) vis.mirror.pt(   x = list(pt.WW, pt.WM),   titles = c("WW", "WM"),   size_titles = 8,   horizon = 5,   breaks_x_left = c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5),   breaks_x_right = c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4),   ord = c(3, 2, 1) )

title: Visualising multi-state models using mstate
text: plots made mstate using use.ggplot = TRUE return ggplot object, can saved desired format using ggplot2::ggsave(). Please refer article written ggplot2 team using ggplot2::ggsave().
code: # Saving a ggplot2 plot p <- plot(pt.WW, use.ggplot = TRUE) ggplot2::ggsave("my_ggplot2_plot.png")  # Standard graphics plot png("my_standard_plot.png") plot(pt.WW, use.ggplot = FALSE) dev.off()

title: Expected length of stay — ELOS
text: Given "probtrans" object, ELOS calculates (restricted) expected length stay states multi-state model.

title: Expected length of stay — ELOS
code: ELOS(pt, tau)

title: Expected length of stay — ELOS
text: pt object class "probtrans" tau horizon ELOS calculated; missing, maximum observed transition times taken

title: Expected length of stay — ELOS
text: K x K matrix (K number states), (g,h)'th element containing E_gh(s,tau). starting time point s inferred pt (smallest time point, equal predt value call probtrans. row- column names matrix named "from1" "fromK" "in1" "inK", respectively.

title: Expected length of stay — ELOS
text: object pt needs "probtrans" object, obtained forward prediction (default, direction="forward", call probtrans). restriction tau , ordinary survival analysis, probability state can positive infinity, resulting infinite values. (restricted, tau) expected length stay state h, given state g time s, given integral s tau P_gh(s,t), see instance Beyersmann Putter (2014).

title: Expected length of stay — ELOS
text: Hein Putter H.Putter@lumc.nl

title: Expected length of stay — ELOS
code: # transition matrix for illness-death model tmat <- trans.illdeath() # data in wide format, for transition 1 this is dataset E1 of # Therneau & Grambsch (2000) tg <- data.frame(illt=c(1,1,6,6,8,9),ills=c(1,0,1,1,0,1),         dt=c(5,1,9,7,8,12),ds=c(1,1,1,1,1,1),         x1=c(1,1,1,0,0,0),x2=c(6:1)) # data in long format using msprep tglong <- msprep(time=c(NA,"illt","dt"),status=c(NA,"ills","ds"),     data=tg,keep=c("x1","x2"),trans=tmat) # events events(tglong) #> $Frequencies #>          to #> from      healthy illness death no event total entering #>   healthy       0       4     2        0              6 #>   illness       0       0     4        0              4 #>   death         0       0     0        6              6 #>  #> $Proportions #>          to #> from        healthy   illness     death  no event #>   healthy 0.0000000 0.6666667 0.3333333 0.0000000 #>   illness 0.0000000 0.0000000 1.0000000 0.0000000 #>   death   0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000 1.0000000 #>  table(tglong$status,tglong$to,tglong$from) #> , ,  = 1 #>  #>     #>     2 3 #>   0 2 4 #>   1 4 2 #>  #> , ,  = 2 #>  #>     #>     2 3 #>   0 0 0 #>   1 0 4 #>  # expanded covariates tglong <- expand.covs(tglong,c("x1","x2")) # Cox model with different covariate cx <- coxph(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status)~x1.1+x2.2+strata(trans),         data=tglong,method="breslow") summary(cx) #> Call: #> coxph(formula = Surv(Tstart, Tstop, status) ~ x1.1 + x2.2 + strata(trans),  #>     data = tglong, method = "breslow") #>  #>   n= 16, number of events= 10  #>  #>        coef exp(coef) se(coef)     z Pr(>|z|) #> x1.1 1.4753    4.3723   1.2557 1.175    0.240 #> x2.2 0.8571    2.3563   0.8848 0.969    0.333 #>  #>      exp(coef) exp(-coef) lower .95 upper .95 #> x1.1     4.372     0.2287    0.3731     51.24 #> x2.2     2.356     0.4244    0.4160     13.35 #>  #> Concordance= 0.781  (se = 0.077 ) #> Likelihood ratio test= 2.93  on 2 df,   p=0.2 #> Wald test            = 2.32  on 2 df,   p=0.3 #> Score (logrank) test = 2.86  on 2 df,   p=0.2 #>  # new data, to check whether results are the same for transition 1 as # those in appendix E.1 of Therneau & Grambsch (2000) newdata <- data.frame(trans=1:3,x1.1=c(0,0,0),x2.2=c(0,1,0),strata=1:3) HvH <- msfit(cx,newdata,trans=tmat) # probtrans pt <- probtrans(HvH,predt=0) # ELOS until last observed time point ELOS(pt) #>            in1      in2      in3 #> from1 7.481061 2.180088  2.33885 #> from2 0.000000 5.000000  7.00000 #> from3 0.000000 0.000000 12.00000 # Restricted ELOS until tau=10 ELOS(pt, tau=10) #>            in1      in2       in3 #> from1 7.481061 1.228543  1.290396 #> from2 0.000000 5.000000  5.000000 #> from3 0.000000 0.000000 10.000000

title: Landmark Aalen-Johansen method — LMAJ
text: function implements landmark Aalen-Johansen method Putter & Spitoni (2016) non-parametric estimation transition probabilities non-Markov models.

title: Landmark Aalen-Johansen method — LMAJ
code: data(prothr) tmat <- attr(prothr, "trans") pr0 <- subset(prothr, treat=="Placebo") attr(pr0, "trans") <- tmat pr1 <- subset(prothr, treat=="Prednisone") attr(pr1, "trans") <- tmat c0 <- coxph(Surv(Tstart, Tstop, status) ~ strata(trans), data=pr0) #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created c1 <- coxph(Surv(Tstart, Tstop, status) ~ strata(trans), data=pr1) #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created msf0 <- msfit(c0, trans=tmat) #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created msf1 <- msfit(c1, trans=tmat) #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created # Comparison as in Figure 2 of Titman (2015) # Aalen-Johansen pt0 <- probtrans(msf0, predt=1000)[[2]] pt1 <- probtrans(msf1, predt=1000)[[2]] par(mfrow=c(1,2)) plot(pt0$time, pt0$pstate1, type="s", lwd=2, xlim=c(1000,4000), ylim=c(0,0.61),      xlab="Time since randomisation (days)", ylab="Probability") lines(pt1$time, pt1$pstate1, type="s", lwd=2, lty=3) legend("topright", c("Placebo", "Prednisone"), lwd=2, lty=1:2, bty="n") title(main="Aalen-Johansen") # Landmark Aalen-Johansen LMpt0 <- LMAJ(msdata=pr0, s=1000, from=2) #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created #> Warning: no non-missing arguments to max; returning -Inf LMpt1 <- LMAJ(msdata=pr1, s=1000, from=2) #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created #> Warning: Stop time must be > start time, NA created #> Warning: no non-missing arguments to max; returning -Inf plot(LMpt0$time, LMpt0$pstate1, type="s", lwd=2, xlim=c(1000,4000), ylim=c(0,0.61),      xlab="Time since randomisation (days)", ylab="Probability") lines(LMpt1$time, LMpt1$pstate1, type="s", lwd=2, lty=3) legend("topright", c("Placebo", "Prednisone"), lwd=2, lty=1:2, bty="n") title(main="Landmark Aalen-Johansen")

title: Log-rank based test for the validity of the Markov assumption — MarkovTest
text: Function MarkovTest performs log-rank test described Titman & Putter (2020). Function optimal_weights_matrix implements optimal weighting state-specific trace. Function optimal_weights_multiple implements optimal weighting chi-squared trace.

title: Log-rank based test for the validity of the Markov assumption — MarkovTest

title: Log-rank based test for the validity of the Markov assumption — MarkovTest
text: Andrew Titman .titman@lancaster.ac.uk, transported mstate Hein Putter H.Putter@lumc.nl

title: Log-rank based test for the validity of the Markov assumption — MarkovTest
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example provided by the prothrombin data data("prothr") # Apply Markov test to grid of monthly time points over the first 7.5 years year <- 365.25 month <- year / 12 grid <- month * (1 : 90) # Markov test for transition 1 (wild bootstrap based on 25 replications, 1000 recommended) MT <- MarkovTest(prothr, id = "id", transition = 1,                  grid = grid, B = 25)  # Plot traces plot(MT, grid, what="states", idx=1:10, states=rownames(attr(prothr, "trans")),      xlab="Days since randomisation", ylab="Log-rank test statistic",      main="Transition Normal -> Low") plot(MT, grid,what="overall", idx=1:10,      xlab="Days since randomisation", ylab="Chi-square test statistic",      main="Transition Normal -> Low")  # Example using optimal weights and adjustment for covariates oweights_fun <-   optimal_weights_matrix(prothr, id = "id", grid=grid, transition = 1,                          other_weights=list(                            function(x) mean(abs(x),na.rm=TRUE),                            function(x) max(abs(x),na.rm=TRUE)))  oweights_chi <- optimal_weights_multiple(prothr, id = "id", grid=grid, transition = 1)  # Formula in MarkovTest only works for continuous covariates and dummy coded variables # No factors allowed prothr$prednisone <- as.numeric(prothr$treat == "Prednisone") MT <- MarkovTest(prothr, id = "id",                   formula = "prednisone",                  transition = 1,                  grid = grid, B = 25,                  fn = oweights_fun,                  fn2 = list(                    function(x) weighted.mean(x, w=oweights_chi, na.rm=TRUE),                    function(x) mean(x, na.rm=TRUE),                    function(x) max(x, na.rm=TRUE))) } # }

title: Function to create weighted data set for competing risks analyses — crprep.default
code: data(aidssi) aidssi.w <- crprep("time", "cause", data=aidssi, trans=c("AIDS","SI"),                    cens="event-free", id="patnr", keep="ccr5")  # calculate cause-specific cumulative incidence, no truncation, # compare with Cuminc (also from mstate) ci <- Cuminc(aidssi$time, aidssi$status) sf <- survfit(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status=="AIDS")~1, data=aidssi.w,               weight=weight.cens, subset=failcode=="AIDS") plot(sf, fun="event", mark.time=FALSE) lines(CI.1~time,data=ci,type="s",col="red")  sf <- survfit(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status=="SI")~1, data=aidssi.w,               weight=weight.cens, subset=failcode=="SI") plot(sf, fun="event", mark.time=FALSE) lines(CI.2~time,data=ci,type="s",col="red")   # Fine and Gray regression for cause 1 cw <- coxph(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status=="AIDS")~ccr5, data=aidssi.w,       weight=weight.cens, subset=failcode=="AIDS") cw #> Call: #> coxph(formula = Surv(Tstart, Tstop, status == "AIDS") ~ ccr5,  #>     data = aidssi.w, weights = weight.cens, subset = failcode ==  #>         "AIDS") #>  #>           coef exp(coef) se(coef) robust se      z        p #> ccr5WM -1.0041    0.3664   0.3057    0.2819 -3.562 0.000368 #>  #> Likelihood ratio test=13.95  on 1 df, p=0.0001881 #> n= 7248, number of events= 113  #>    (43 observations deleted due to missingness) # This can be checked with the results of crr (cmprsk) # crr(ftime=aidssi$time, fstatus=aidssi$status, cov1=as.numeric(aidssi$ccr5))  # Gray's log-rank test aidssi.wCCR <- crprep("time", "cause", data=aidssi, trans=c("AIDS","SI"),                       cens="event-free", id="patnr", strata="ccr5") test.AIDS <- coxph(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status=="AIDS")~ccr5, data=aidssi.wCCR,                    weights=weight.cens, subset=failcode=="AIDS") test.SI <- coxph(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status=="SI")~ccr5, data=aidssi.wCCR,                  weights=weight.cens, subset=failcode=="SI") ## score test statistic and p-value c(test.AIDS$score, 1-pchisq(test.AIDS$score,1)) # AIDS #> [1] 1.296891e+01 3.167068e-04 c(test.SI$score, 1-pchisq(test.SI$score,1))     # SI #> [1] 0.3941795 0.5301106 # This can be compared with the results of cuminc (cmprsk) # with(aidssi, cuminc(time, status, group=ccr5)$Tests) # Note: results are not exactly the same

code: # Transition matrix for illness-death model tmat <- trans.illdeath() # Data in wide format, for transition 1 this is dataset E1 of # Therneau & Grambsch (T&G) tg <- data.frame(id=1:6,illt=c(1,1,6,6,8,9),ills=c(1,0,1,1,0,1),                  dt=c(5,1,9,7,8,12),ds=c(1,1,1,1,1,1),                  x1=c(1,1,1,0,0,0),x2=c(6:1)) # Data in long format using msprep tglong <- msprep(time=c(NA,"illt","dt"),status=c(NA,"ills","ds"),                  data=tg,keep=c("x1","x2"),trans=tmat, id="id") # Same thing in etm format tra <- trans2tra(tmat) tgetm <- msdata2etm(tglong, id="id") tgetm <- msdata2etm(tglong, id="id", covs=c("x1", "x2")) # with covariates # And back etm2msdata(tgetm, id="id", tra=tra) #> An object of class 'msdata' #>  #> Data: #>    id from to trans Tstart Tstop time status #> 1   1    1  2     1      0     1    1      1 #> 2   1    1  3     2      0     1    1      0 #> 3   1    2  3     3      1     5    4      1 #> 4   2    1  2     1      0     1    1      0 #> 5   2    1  3     2      0     1    1      1 #> 6   3    1  2     1      0     6    6      1 #> 7   3    1  3     2      0     6    6      0 #> 8   3    2  3     3      6     9    3      1 #> 9   4    1  2     1      0     6    6      1 #> 10  4    1  3     2      0     6    6      0 #> 11  4    2  3     3      6     7    1      1 #> 12  5    1  2     1      0     8    8      0 #> 13  5    1  3     2      0     8    8      1 #> 14  6    1  2     1      0     9    9      1 #> 15  6    1  3     2      0     9    9      0 #> 16  6    2  3     3      9    12    3      1 etm2msdata(tgetm, id="id", tra=tra, covs=c("x1", "x2")) # with covariates #> An object of class 'msdata' #>  #> Data: #>    id from to trans Tstart Tstop time status x1 x2 #> 1   1    1  2     1      0     1    1      1  1  6 #> 2   1    1  3     2      0     1    1      0  1  6 #> 3   1    2  3     3      1     5    4      1  1  6 #> 4   2    1  2     1      0     1    1      0  1  5 #> 5   2    1  3     2      0     1    1      1  1  5 #> 6   3    1  2     1      0     6    6      1  1  4 #> 7   3    1  3     2      0     6    6      0  1  4 #> 8   3    2  3     3      6     9    3      1  1  4 #> 9   4    1  2     1      0     6    6      1  0  3 #> 10  4    1  3     2      0     6    6      0  0  3 #> 11  4    2  3     3      6     7    1      1  0  3 #> 12  5    1  2     1      0     8    8      0  0  2 #> 13  5    1  3     2      0     8    8      1  0  2 #> 14  6    1  2     1      0     9    9      1  0  1 #> 15  6    1  3     2      0     9    9      0  0  1 #> 16  6    2  3     3      9    12    3      1  0  1

title: Bootstrap function in multi-state models — msboot
code: tmat <- trans.illdeath() data(ebmt1) covs <- c("score","yrel") msebmt <- msprep(time=c(NA,"rel","srv"),status=c(NA,"relstat","srvstat"),     data=ebmt1,id="patid",keep=covs,trans=tmat) # define a function (this one returns vector of regression coef's) regcoefvec <- function(data) {   cx <- coxph(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status)~score+strata(trans),           data=data,method="breslow")   return(coef(cx)) } regcoefvec(msebmt) #> scoreMedium risk   scoreHigh risk  #>         0.545701         1.191317  set.seed(1234) msboot(theta=regcoefvec,data=msebmt,id="patid") #>           [,1]     [,2]      [,3]     [,4]      [,5] #> [1,] 0.4219375 0.539130 0.6494073 0.558677 0.3129345 #> [2,] 0.9633390 1.277396 1.2860004 1.340357 1.0736761

title: Extend a multi-state model using relative survival — msfit.relsurv
text: Manevski D, Putter H, Pohar Perme M, Bonneville EF, Schetelig J, de Wreede LC (2021). Integrating relative survival multi-state models – non-parametric approach. https://arxiv.org/abs/2106.12399

title: Extend a multi-state model using relative survival — msfit.relsurv
text: Damjan Manevski damjan.manevski@mf.uni-lj.si

title: Extend a multi-state model using relative survival — msfit.relsurv
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ library(mstate) # Load dataset: data("ebmt1") # Transition matrix: tmat <- transMat(list(c(2,3),c(4), c(), c()),                   names = c("Alive relapse-free", "Relapse","NRM", "DaR")) # Data in long format using msprep df <- msprep(time=c(NA,"rel","srv","srv"), status=c(NA,"relstat","srvstat","srvstat"),              data=ebmt1, trans=tmat) # Generate demographic covariates (which are usually present in datasets)  # and based on them estimate the population hazard. set.seed(510) df$age <- runif(nrow(df), 45, 65) df$sex <- sample(c("male", "female"), size = nrow(df), replace = TRUE) df$dateHCT <- sample(seq(as.Date('1990/01/01'),      as.Date('2000/01/01'), by="day"), nrow(df), replace = TRUE) # generate years # Cox object: cx <- coxph(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status)~strata(trans),             data=df,method="breslow") # Basic multi-state model: mod <- msfit(cx,trans=tmat) # Extended multi-state model, where the two transition # reaching death are split in excess and population parts. # We assume patients live like in the Slovene population, # thus we use Slovene mortality tables in this example. # Variances estimated using 25 bootstrap replications. mod.relsurv <- msfit.relsurv(msfit.obj = mod, data=df, split.transitions = c(2,3),                             ratetable = relsurv::slopop,                              rmap = list(age=age*365.241, year=dateHCT),                             time.format = "days",                             var.pop.haz = "bootstrap",                             B = 25) # Estimate transition probabilities: pt <- probtrans(mod.relsurv, predt=0, method='greenwood') # Estimated cumulative hazards with the corresponding  # bootstrap standard errors at 300, 600, 900 days: summary(object = mod.relsurv, times = c(300, 600, 900), conf.type = 'log') # Estimated transition probabilities together with the corresponding  # bootstrap standard errors and log.boot confidence intervals  # at 300, 600, 900 days: summary(object = pt, times = c(300, 600, 900), conf.type = 'log') # Plot the measures: plot(mod.relsurv, use.ggplot = TRUE) plot(pt, use.ggplot = TRUE) } # }

status and covariates also as matrices tt <- matrix(c(rep(NA,6),tg$illt,tg$dt),6,3) st <- matrix(c(rep(NA,6),tg$ills,tg$ds),6,3) keepmat <- data.frame(gender=tg$x1,age=tg$x2) # data in long format code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example provided by the prothrombin data data("prothr") # Apply Markov test to grid of monthly time points over the first 7.5 years year <- 365.25 month <- year / 12 grid <- month * (1:90) # Markov test for transition 1 (wild bootstrap based on 100 replications) MT <- MarkovTest(prothr, id = "id", transition = 1,                  grid = grid, B = 100)  plot(MT, grid, what="states", idx=1:50, states=rownames(attr(prothr, "trans")),      xlab="Days since randomisation", ylab="Log-rank test statistic",      main="Transition Normal -> Low")  plot(MT, grid,what="overall", idx=1:50,      xlab="Days since randomisation", ylab="Chi-square test statistic",      main="Transition Normal -> Low")  plot(MT, grid, what="states", quantiles=FALSE) # only trace plot(MT, grid, what="states") # trace plus quantiles (default) plot(MT, grid, what="states", idx=1:10) # trace plus quantiles, plus first 10 bootstrap traces   plot(MT, grid, what="overall", quantiles=FALSE) # only trace plot(MT, grid, what="overall") # trace plus quantiles (default) plot(MT, grid, what="overall", idx=1:10) # trace plus quantiles, plus first 10 bootstrap traces  } # }

title: Plot method for an msfit object — plot.msfit
code: # transition matrix for illness-death model tmat <- trans.illdeath() # data in wide format, for transition 1 this is dataset E1 of # Therneau & Grambsch (2000) tg <- data.frame(illt=c(1,1,6,6,8,9),ills=c(1,0,1,1,0,1),         dt=c(5,1,9,7,8,12),ds=c(1,1,1,1,1,1),         x1=c(1,1,1,0,0,0),x2=c(6:1)) # data in long format using msprep tglong <- msprep(time=c(NA,"illt","dt"),status=c(NA,"ills","ds"),     data=tg,keep=c("x1","x2"),trans=tmat) # events events(tglong) #> $Frequencies #>          to #> from      healthy illness death no event total entering #>   healthy       0       4     2        0              6 #>   illness       0       0     4        0              4 #>   death         0       0     0        6              6 #>  #> $Proportions #>          to #> from        healthy   illness     death  no event #>   healthy 0.0000000 0.6666667 0.3333333 0.0000000 #>   illness 0.0000000 0.0000000 1.0000000 0.0000000 #>   death   0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000 1.0000000 #>  table(tglong$status,tglong$to,tglong$from) #> , ,  = 1 #>  #>     #>     2 3 #>   0 2 4 #>   1 4 2 #>  #> , ,  = 2 #>  #>     #>     2 3 #>   0 0 0 #>   1 0 4 #>  # expanded covariates tglong <- expand.covs(tglong,c("x1","x2")) # Cox model with different covariate cx <- coxph(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status)~x1.1+x2.2+strata(trans),   data=tglong,method="breslow") summary(cx) #> Call: #> coxph(formula = Surv(Tstart, Tstop, status) ~ x1.1 + x2.2 + strata(trans),  #>     data = tglong, method = "breslow") #>  #>   n= 16, number of events= 10  #>  #>        coef exp(coef) se(coef)     z Pr(>|z|) #> x1.1 1.4753    4.3723   1.2557 1.175    0.240 #> x2.2 0.8571    2.3563   0.8848 0.969    0.333 #>  #>      exp(coef) exp(-coef) lower .95 upper .95 #> x1.1     4.372     0.2287    0.3731     51.24 #> x2.2     2.356     0.4244    0.4160     13.35 #>  #> Concordance= 0.781  (se = 0.077 ) #> Likelihood ratio test= 2.93  on 2 df,   p=0.2 #> Wald test            = 2.32  on 2 df,   p=0.3 #> Score (logrank) test = 2.86  on 2 df,   p=0.2 #>  # new data, to check whether results are the same for transition 1 as # those in appendix E.1 of Therneau & Grambsch (2000) newdata <- data.frame(trans=1:3,x1.1=c(0,0,0),x2.2=c(0,1,0),strata=1:3) msf <- msfit(cx,newdata,trans=tmat) # standard plot plot(msf)  # specifying line width, color, and legend plot(msf,lwd=2,col=c("darkgreen","darkblue","darkred"),legend=c("1->2","1->3","2->3"))  # separate plots par(mfrow=c(2,2)) plot(msf,type="separate",lwd=2) par(mfrow=c(1,1))   # ggplot version - see vignette for details library(ggplot2) plot(msf, use.ggplot = TRUE)

code: # transition matrix for illness-death model tmat <- trans.illdeath() # data in wide format, for transition 1 this is dataset E1 of # Therneau and Grambsch (2000) tg <- data.frame(illt=c(1,1,6,6,8,9),ills=c(1,0,1,1,0,1),         dt=c(5,1,9,7,8,12),ds=c(1,1,1,1,1,1),         x1=c(1,1,1,0,0,0),x2=c(6:1)) # data in long format using msprep tglong <- msprep(time=c(NA,"illt","dt"),status=c(NA,"ills","ds"),     data=tg,keep=c("x1","x2"),trans=tmat) # events events(tglong) #> $Frequencies #>          to #> from      healthy illness death no event total entering #>   healthy       0       4     2        0              6 #>   illness       0       0     4        0              4 #>   death         0       0     0        6              6 #>  #> $Proportions #>          to #> from        healthy   illness     death  no event #>   healthy 0.0000000 0.6666667 0.3333333 0.0000000 #>   illness 0.0000000 0.0000000 1.0000000 0.0000000 #>   death   0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000 1.0000000 #>  table(tglong$status,tglong$to,tglong$from) #> , ,  = 1 #>  #>     #>     2 3 #>   0 2 4 #>   1 4 2 #>  #> , ,  = 2 #>  #>     #>     2 3 #>   0 0 0 #>   1 0 4 #>  # expanded covariates tglong <- expand.covs(tglong,c("x1","x2")) # Cox model with different covariate cx <- coxph(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status)~x1.1+x2.2+strata(trans),   data=tglong,method="breslow") summary(cx) #> Call: #> coxph(formula = Surv(Tstart, Tstop, status) ~ x1.1 + x2.2 + strata(trans),  #>     data = tglong, method = "breslow") #>  #>   n= 16, number of events= 10  #>  #>        coef exp(coef) se(coef)     z Pr(>|z|) #> x1.1 1.4753    4.3723   1.2557 1.175    0.240 #> x2.2 0.8571    2.3563   0.8848 0.969    0.333 #>  #>      exp(coef) exp(-coef) lower .95 upper .95 #> x1.1     4.372     0.2287    0.3731     51.24 #> x2.2     2.356     0.4244    0.4160     13.35 #>  #> Concordance= 0.781  (se = 0.077 ) #> Likelihood ratio test= 2.93  on 2 df,   p=0.2 #> Wald test            = 2.32  on 2 df,   p=0.3 #> Score (logrank) test = 2.86  on 2 df,   p=0.2 #>  # new data, to check whether results are the same for transition 1 as # those in appendix E.1 of Therneau and Grambsch (2000) newdata <- data.frame(trans=1:3,x1.1=c(0,0,0),x2.2=c(0,1,0),strata=1:3) msf <- msfit(cx,newdata,trans=tmat) # probtrans pt <- probtrans(msf,predt=0) # default plot plot(pt,ord=c(2,3,1),lwd=2,cex=0.75)  # filled plot plot(pt,type="filled",ord=c(2,3,1),lwd=2,cex=0.75) # single plot plot(pt,type="single",lwd=2,col=rep(1,3),lty=1:3,legend.pos=c(8,1))  # separate plots par(mfrow=c(2,2)) plot(pt,type="sep",lwd=2) par(mfrow=c(1,1))   # ggplot version - see vignette for details library(ggplot2) plot(pt, ord=c(2,3,1), use.ggplot = TRUE)

text: Liesbeth de Wreede Hein Putter H.Putter@lumc.nl

title: Compute subject-specific or overall transition probabilities with standard errors — probtrans
code: # transition matrix for illness-death model tmat <- trans.illdeath() # data in wide format, for transition 1 this is dataset E1 of # Therneau & Grambsch (2000) tg <- data.frame(illt=c(1,1,6,6,8,9),ills=c(1,0,1,1,0,1),         dt=c(5,1,9,7,8,12),ds=c(1,1,1,1,1,1),         x1=c(1,1,1,0,0,0),x2=c(6:1)) # data in long format using msprep tglong <- msprep(time=c(NA,"illt","dt"),status=c(NA,"ills","ds"),     data=tg,keep=c("x1","x2"),trans=tmat) # events events(tglong) #> $Frequencies #>          to #> from      healthy illness death no event total entering #>   healthy       0       4     2        0              6 #>   illness       0       0     4        0              4 #>   death         0       0     0        6              6 #>  #> $Proportions #>          to #> from        healthy   illness     death  no event #>   healthy 0.0000000 0.6666667 0.3333333 0.0000000 #>   illness 0.0000000 0.0000000 1.0000000 0.0000000 #>   death   0.0000000 0.0000000 0.0000000 1.0000000 #>  table(tglong$status,tglong$to,tglong$from) #> , ,  = 1 #>  #>     #>     2 3 #>   0 2 4 #>   1 4 2 #>  #> , ,  = 2 #>  #>     #>     2 3 #>   0 0 0 #>   1 0 4 #>  # expanded covariates tglong <- expand.covs(tglong,c("x1","x2")) # Cox model with different covariate cx <- coxph(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status)~x1.1+x2.2+strata(trans),         data=tglong,method="breslow") summary(cx) #> Call: #> coxph(formula = Surv(Tstart, Tstop, status) ~ x1.1 + x2.2 + strata(trans),  #>     data = tglong, method = "breslow") #>  #>   n= 16, number of events= 10  #>  #>        coef exp(coef) se(coef)     z Pr(>|z|) #> x1.1 1.4753    4.3723   1.2557 1.175    0.240 #> x2.2 0.8571    2.3563   0.8848 0.969    0.333 #>  #>      exp(coef) exp(-coef) lower .95 upper .95 #> x1.1     4.372     0.2287    0.3731     51.24 #> x2.2     2.356     0.4244    0.4160     13.35 #>  #> Concordance= 0.781  (se = 0.077 ) #> Likelihood ratio test= 2.93  on 2 df,   p=0.2 #> Wald test            = 2.32  on 2 df,   p=0.3 #> Score (logrank) test = 2.86  on 2 df,   p=0.2 #>  # new data, to check whether results are the same for transition 1 as # those in appendix E.1 of Therneau & Grambsch (2000) newdata <- data.frame(trans=1:3,x1.1=c(0,0,0),x2.2=c(0,1,0),strata=1:3) HvH <- msfit(cx,newdata,trans=tmat) # probtrans pt <- probtrans(HvH,predt=0) # predictions from state 1 pt[[1]] #>   time   pstate1    pstate2     pstate3        se1        se2        se3 #> 1    0 1.0000000 0.00000000 0.000000000 0.00000000 0.00000000 0.00000000 #> 2    1 0.9299816 0.06204689 0.007971491 0.08750408 0.08250577 0.02915069 #> 3    5 0.9299816 0.00000000 0.070018378 0.08750408 0.00000000 0.08750408 #> 4    6 0.6776902 0.25229141 0.070018378 0.22689332 0.21903899 0.08750408 #> 5    7 0.6776902 0.12614570 0.196164083 0.22689332 0.12638316 0.14680748 #> 6    8 0.4757726 0.12614570 0.398081646 0.23614089 0.12638316 0.19877253 #> 7    9 0.0000000 0.47577265 0.524227350 0.00000000 0.53115171 0.53115171 #> 8   12 0.0000000 0.00000000 1.000000000 0.00000000 0.00000000 0.00000000

Reduced-rank proportional hazards regression simulation-based prediction multi-state models. Statistics Medicine 27, 4340–4358. Putter H, Fiocco M, Geskus RB (2007). title: Reduced rank proportional hazards model for competing risks and multi-state models — redrank
text: Marta Fiocco Hein Putter H.Putter@lumc.nl

title: Reduced rank proportional hazards model for competing risks and multi-state models — redrank
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{     # This reproduces the results in Fiocco, Putter & van Houwelingen (2005)     # Takes a while to run     data(ebmt2)     # transition matrix for competing risks     tmat <- trans.comprisk(6,names=c("Relapse","GvHD","Bacterial","Viral","Fungal","Other"))     # preparing long dataset     ebmt2$stat1 <- as.numeric(ebmt2$status==1)     ebmt2$stat2 <- as.numeric(ebmt2$status==2)     ebmt2$stat3 <- as.numeric(ebmt2$status==3)     ebmt2$stat4 <- as.numeric(ebmt2$status==4)     ebmt2$stat5 <- as.numeric(ebmt2$status==5)     ebmt2$stat6 <- as.numeric(ebmt2$status==6)     covs <- c("dissub","match","tcd","year","age")     ebmtlong <- msprep(time=c(NA,rep("time",6)),                        stat=c(NA,paste("stat",1:6,sep="")),                        data=ebmt2,keep=covs,trans=tmat)      # The reduced rank 2 solution     rr2 <- redrank(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status) ~ dissub+match+tcd+year+age,                    data=ebmtlong, R=2)     rr3$Alpha; rr3$Gamma; rr3$Beta; rr3$loglik     # The reduced rank 3 solution     rr3 <- redrank(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status) ~ dissub+match+tcd+year+age,                    data=ebmtlong, R=3)     rr3$Alpha; rr3$Gamma; rr3$Beta; rr3$loglik     # The reduced rank 3 solution, with no reduction on age     rr3 <- redrank(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status) ~ dissub+match+tcd+year, full=~age,                    data=ebmtlong, R=3)     rr3$Alpha; rr3$Gamma; rr3$Beta; rr3$loglik     # The full rank solution     fullrank <- redrank(Surv(Tstart,Tstop,status) ~ dissub+match+tcd+year+age,                         data=ebmtlong, R=6)     fullrank$Beta; fullrank$loglik } # }

text: x List possible transitions; x[[]] consists vector state numbers reachable state names character vector containing names either competing risks states multi-state model specified competing risks illness-death model. names length list x (transMat), either K K+1 (trans.comprisk), 3 (trans.illdeath)

text: transition matrix describing states transitions multi-state model.

title: Define transition matrix for multi-state model — transMat
text: names missing, names "eventfree", "cause1", etcetera assigned trans.comprisk, "healthy", "illness", "death" trans.illdeath.

title: Define transition matrix for multi-state model — transMat
text: Steven McKinney <smckinney@bccrc.ca>; Hein Putter <H.Putter@lumc.nl>

title: Define transition matrix for multi-state model — transMat
code: transMat(list(c(2, 3), c(), c(1, 2)),   names = c("Disease-free", "Death", "Relapsed")) #>               to #> from           Disease-free Death Relapsed #>   Disease-free           NA     1        2 #>   Death                  NA    NA       NA #>   Relapsed                3     4       NA tmat <- transMat(x = list( c(2, 3), c(1, 3), c() ),                  names = c("Normal", "Low", "Death")) tmat #>         to #> from     Normal Low Death #>   Normal     NA   1     2 #>   Low         3  NA     4 #>   Death      NA  NA    NA transListn <- list("Normal" = c(2, 3), "Low" = c(1, 3), "Death" = c()) transMat(transListn) #>         to #> from     Normal Low Death #>   Normal     NA   1     2 #>   Low         3  NA     4 #>   Death      NA  NA    NA trans.comprisk(3) #>            to #> from        eventfree cause1 cause2 cause3 #>   eventfree        NA      1      2      3 #>   cause1           NA     NA     NA     NA #>   cause2           NA     NA     NA     NA #>   cause3           NA     NA     NA     NA trans.comprisk(3,c("c1","c2","c3")) #>            to #> from        eventfree c1 c2 c3 #>   eventfree        NA  1  2  3 #>   c1               NA NA NA NA #>   c2               NA NA NA NA #>   c3               NA NA NA NA trans.comprisk(3,c("nothing","c1","c2","c3")) #>          to #> from      nothing c1 c2 c3 #>   nothing      NA  1  2  3 #>   c1           NA NA NA NA #>   c2           NA NA NA NA #>   c3           NA NA NA NA trans.illdeath() #>          to #> from      healthy illness death #>   healthy      NA       1     2 #>   illness      NA      NA     3 #>   death        NA      NA    NA trans.illdeath(c("nothing","ill","death")) #>          to #> from      nothing ill death #>   nothing      NA   1     2 #>   ill          NA  NA     3 #>   death        NA  NA    NA

title: Help functions for transition matrix — transhelp
text: Function .trans2 simply lists transitions trans data frame; function trans2Q converts trans Q matrix, (j,k)th element contains (shortest) number transitions needed travel jth kth state; function absorbing returns vector (named trans contains row columnc names) state numbers absorbing; function .circular returns (Boolean) whether transition matrix specified trans circular .

title: Help functions for transition matrix — transhelp
text: Hein Putter <H.Putter@lumc.nl>

title: Help functions for transition matrix — transhelp
code: # Irreversible illness-death model tmat <- trans.illdeath(c("Healthy", "Illness", "Death")) tmat #>          to #> from      Healthy Illness Death #>   Healthy      NA       1     2 #>   Illness      NA      NA     3 #>   Death        NA      NA    NA to.trans2(tmat) #>   transno from to fromname  toname          transname #> 1       1    1  2  Healthy Illness Healthy -> Illness #> 2       2    1  3  Healthy   Death   Healthy -> Death #> 3       3    2  3  Illness   Death   Illness -> Death trans2Q(tmat) #>          to #> from      Healthy Illness Death #>   Healthy       0       1     1 #>   Illness       0       0     1 #>   Death         0       0     0 absorbing(tmat) #> Death  #>     3  is.circular(tmat) #> [1] FALSE # Reversible illness-death model tmat <- transMat(x = list( c(2, 3), c(1, 3), c() ),                  names = c("Healthy", "Illness", "Death")) tmat #>          to #> from      Healthy Illness Death #>   Healthy      NA       1     2 #>   Illness       3      NA     4 #>   Death        NA      NA    NA to.trans2(tmat) #>   transno from to fromname  toname          transname #> 1       1    1  2  Healthy Illness Healthy -> Illness #> 2       2    1  3  Healthy   Death   Healthy -> Death #> 3       3    2  1  Illness Healthy Illness -> Healthy #> 4       4    2  3  Illness   Death   Illness -> Death trans2Q(tmat) #>          to #> from      Healthy Illness Death #>   Healthy       2       1     1 #>   Illness       1       2     1 #>   Death         0       0     0 absorbing(tmat) #> Death  #>     3  is.circular(tmat) #> [1] TRUE

code: vis.mirror.pt(   x,   titles,   size_titles = 5,   horizon = NULL,   breaks_x_left,   breaks_x_right,   from = 1,   cols,   ord,   xlab = "Time",   ylab = "Probability",   legend.pos = "right" )

title: Mirror plot comparing two probtrans objects — vis.mirror.pt
text: x list two "probtrans" objects. first element left mirror plot, second right titles character vector c("Title left", "Title right") size_titles Numeric, size title text horizon Numeric, position denoting (time) symmetrically mirror plots. Default maximum follow-plots. breaks_x_left Numeric vector specifying axis breaks left plot breaks_x_right Numeric vector specifying axis breaks right plot starting state probabilities used plot cols vector specifying colors different transitions; default palette green red, type="filled" (reordered according ord, 1 (black), otherwise ord vector length equal number states, specifying order plotting case type="stacked" "filled" xlab title x-axis, default "Time" ylab title y-axis, default "Probability" legend.pos Position legend, default "right"

title: Mirror plot comparing two probtrans objects — vis.mirror.pt
text: ggplot2 object.

title: Mirror plot comparing two probtrans objects — vis.mirror.pt
text: Edouard F. Bonneville e.f.bonneville@lumc.nl

title: Mirror plot comparing two probtrans objects — vis.mirror.pt
code: library(ggplot2)  data("aidssi") head(aidssi) #>   patnr   time status      cause ccr5 #> 1     1  9.106      1       AIDS   WW #> 2     2 11.039      0 event-free   WM #> 3     3  2.234      1       AIDS   WW #> 4     4  9.878      2         SI   WM #> 5     5  3.819      1       AIDS   WW #> 6     6  6.801      1       AIDS   WW si <- aidssi  # Prepare transition matrix tmat <- trans.comprisk(2, names = c("event-free", "AIDS", "SI"))  # Run msprep si$stat1 <- as.numeric(si$status == 1) si$stat2 <- as.numeric(si$status == 2)  silong <- msprep( time = c(NA, "time", "time"),  status = c(NA, "stat1", "stat2"),  data = si, keep = "ccr5", trans = tmat )  # Run cox model silong <- expand.covs(silong, "ccr5") c1 <- coxph(Surv(time, status) ~ ccr5WM.1 + ccr5WM.2 + strata(trans),             data = silong)              # 1. Prepare reference patient data - both CCR5 genotypes WW <- data.frame( ccr5WM.1 = c(0, 0),  ccr5WM.2 = c(0, 0),  trans = c(1, 2),  strata = c(1, 2) )  WM <- data.frame( ccr5WM.1 = c(1, 0),  ccr5WM.2 = c(0, 1), trans = c(1, 2),  strata = c(1, 2) )  # 2. Make msfit objects msf.WW <- msfit(c1, WW, trans = tmat) msf.WM <- msfit(c1, WM, trans = tmat)  # 3. Make probtrans objects pt.WW <- probtrans(msf.WW, predt = 0) pt.WM <- probtrans(msf.WM, predt = 0)             # Mirror plot split at 10 years - see vignette for more details vis.mirror.pt( x = list(pt.WW, pt.WM), titles = c("WW", "WM"), horizon = 10 )

title: Visualise multiple probtrans objects — vis.multiple.pt
text: Helper function allowing visualise state probabilities different reference patients/covariates. Multiple "probtrans" objects thus needed.

title: Visualise multiple probtrans objects — vis.multiple.pt
code: vis.multiple.pt(   x,   from = 1,   to,   xlab = "Time",   ylab = "Probability",   xlim = NULL,   ylim = NULL,   cols,   lwd,   labels,   conf.int = 0.95,   conf.type = c("log", "plain", "none"),   legend.title )

title: Visualise multiple probtrans objects — vis.multiple.pt
text: x list "probtrans" objects starting state probabilities used plot Numeric, plot.probtrans (Numeric) destination state xlab title x-axis; default "Time" ylab title y-axis; default "Probability" xlim x limits plot(s), default range time ylim y limits plot(s); ylim specified type="separate", plots use ylim y limits cols vector specifying colors different transitions; default palette green red, type="filled" (reordered according ord, 1 (black), otherwise lwd line width, see par; default 1 labels Character vector labelling element x (e.g. label reference patient) - labels = c("Patient 1", "Patient 2") conf.int Confidence level (%) 0-1 probabilities, default 0.95 (95% CI). Setting 0 removes CIs. conf.type Type confidence interval - either "log" "plain" . See function details details. legend.title Character - title legend

title: Visualise multiple probtrans objects — vis.multiple.pt
text: ggplot object.

title: Visualise multiple probtrans objects — vis.multiple.pt
text: Edouard F. Bonneville e.f.bonneville@lumc.nl

title: Visualise multiple probtrans objects — vis.multiple.pt
code: library(ggplot2)  data("aidssi") head(aidssi) #>   patnr   time status      cause ccr5 #> 1     1  9.106      1       AIDS   WW #> 2     2 11.039      0 event-free   WM #> 3     3  2.234      1       AIDS   WW #> 4     4  9.878      2         SI   WM #> 5     5  3.819      1       AIDS   WW #> 6     6  6.801      1       AIDS   WW si <- aidssi  # Prepare transition matrix tmat <- trans.comprisk(2, names = c("event-free", "AIDS", "SI"))  # Run msprep si$stat1 <- as.numeric(si$status == 1) si$stat2 <- as.numeric(si$status == 2)  silong <- msprep( time = c(NA, "time", "time"),  status = c(NA, "stat1", "stat2"),  data = si, keep = "ccr5", trans = tmat )  # Run cox model silong <- expand.covs(silong, "ccr5") c1 <- coxph(Surv(time, status) ~ ccr5WM.1 + ccr5WM.2 + strata(trans),             data = silong)              # 1. Prepare patient data - both CCR5 genotypes WW <- data.frame( ccr5WM.1 = c(0, 0),  ccr5WM.2 = c(0, 0),  trans = c(1, 2),  strata = c(1, 2) )  WM <- data.frame( ccr5WM.1 = c(1, 0),  ccr5WM.2 = c(0, 1), trans = c(1, 2),  strata = c(1, 2) )  # 2. Make msfit objects msf.WW <- msfit(c1, WW, trans = tmat) msf.WM <- msfit(c1, WM, trans = tmat)  # 3. Make probtrans objects pt.WW <- probtrans(msf.WW, predt = 0) pt.WM <- probtrans(msf.WM, predt = 0)             # Plot - see vignette for more details vis.multiple.pt( x = list(pt.WW, pt.WM),  from = 1, to = 2,  conf.type = "log", cols = c(1, 2), labels = c("Pat WW", "Pat WM"), legend.title = "Ref patients" )

title: Version 0.2.9 (2016-02-28)
text: CRAN release: 2016-02-29 Repaired small bug msprep introduced # Version 0.2.8, case one covariate. Added LMAJ function estimate non-parametrically transition probabilities possibly non-Markov multi-state models. LMAJ stands landmark Aalen-Johansen.

title: Version 0.2.8 (2015-12-05)
text: CRAN release: 2015-12-06 crprep function. Object orientation introduced. Function renamed crprep.default. Code calculates weights rewritten. contains extra argument “strata” computes value-specific weights. Fixed errors affect way id keep columns presented. Default value prec.factor changed 1000 (100, values may correct case ties). Many changes help file. Creation counting process data set function create.wData.omega. Added aidssi2 data set, contains data multi-state analyses. Many changes help file aidssi. expand.covs function. Object orientation introduced. Renamed expand.covs.mstate. expand.covs.default used competing risks data sets. Repaired bug events function. Rows corresponding absorbing states empty. numbers entering absorbing states longer 0. Added Tentry time resulting data frame cutLMms function. Warning added ELOS, case negative predicted proabilities. Dimension check beta.state mssample repaired. msprep function, id keep now correctly handled. Time points fixedhor prediction corrected probtrans. plot.probtrans, correct handling now lty, lwd, col etc. Cuminc function effectively made obsolete. backward compatibility, “redefined” calling survfit type=“mstate” translating output used . Print, plot summary methods survfit. Subsetting like survfit objects possible. functionality defining events failcodes gone.

title: Version 0.2.7 (2014-05-29)
text: CRAN release: 2014-05-30 Added function cutLMms (mirrored cutLM dynpred) cuts multi- state data frame (object type “msdata”) landmark time point LM; administrative censoring one common time point also supported Added function xsect takes cross-section particular time point Added function ELOS calculates expected length stay (ELOS) probtrans object Added disclaimers EBMT data sets Repaired bug example events() Made much user-friendlier # Version covariance matrix (list element K+1 K states) probtrans. NOTE: dimension changed nt x K^2 x K^2 (nt distinct transition time points) K^2 x K^2 x (nt+1); extra time point (time 0) also present column “time” data frames [[1]] [[K]], containing transition probabilities SE’s. plot.msfit now uses names rather numbers transitions (set legend=1:K don’t want (K transitions)) Changed default colors plot.probtrans Fixed bug plot.probtrans misplaced text filled stacked probability plots xlim set Fixed lwd bugs plot.msfit plot.probtrans Citation Geskus, Biometrics 2010, updated

title: Version 0.2.4 (2010-05-12)
text: CRAN release: 2010-06-02 ebmt4 dataset adapted; recovery adverse event abstracted. Simultaneous occurrences recovery adverse events removed; adapted recoveries occur half day earlier. Also simultaneous relapse death set relapse, death status set 0. new variable recae created, defined time recovery AE obtained. corresponding status variable recae.s 1 case patient experienced recovery AE. probtrans, argument direction now can take values “forward” “fixedhorizon”. option “fixedhorizon” previously called “backward”. summary method probtrans, bug beeen fixed. summary used show head head, changed head tail. msfit, newdata argument now first sorted according trans function redrank now asks two formulas, rather two character strings containing column names data reduced rank full covariates xlim added explicit argument plot.probtrans Error fixed handling last time point msfit
